abstract.text: One of the main objectives of the NA61/SHINE experiment at the CERN SPS is to study properties of strongly interacting matter.
This paper presents new results on observables relevant for this part of the NA61/SHINE programme.
These include the first ever measurements of φ meson production in p+p collisions at 40 and 80 GeV, and most detailed ever experimental data at 158 GeV.
This contribution demonstrates the superior accuracy of the present dataset with respect to existing measurements.
The comparison of p+p to Pb+Pb collisions shows a non-trivial system size dependence of the longitudinal evolution of hidden strangeness production, contrasting with that of other mesons.

Furthermore, proton density fluctuations are investigated as a possible order parameter of the second order phase transition in the neighbourhood of the critical point (CP) of strongly interacting matter.
An intermittency analysis is performed of the proton second scaled factorial moments in transverse momentum space.
A previous analysis of this sort revealed significant power-law fluctuations for the "Si"+Si system at 158A GeV measured by the NA49 experiment.

The fitted power-law exponent was consistent within errors with the theoretically expected critical value, a result suggesting a baryochemical potential in the vicinity of the CP of about 250 MeV [24].
The analysis will now be extended to NA61/SHINE systems of similar size, Be+Be and Ar+Sc, at 150A GeV.

Finally, spectator-induced electromagnetic (EM) effects on charged meson production are being studied and bring information on the space-time position of the pion formation zone, which appears to be much closer to the spectator system for faster pions than for slower ones.
On that basis, we demonstrate that the longitudinal evolution of the system at CERN SPS energies may be interpreted as a pure consequence of local energymomentum conservation.

body_text.text: Introduction
NA61/SHINE [1] is a fixed target experiment at the CERN SPS accelerator complex.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Its strong interactions programme is a continuation and extension of the NA49 experiment [2], following NA49's discovery of the onset of deconfinement in Pb+Pb collisions at 30A GeV beam momentum [3,4].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: NA61/SHINE performs the first two-dimensional scan of the phase diagram of strongly interacting matter (SIM) by varying the momentum and size of the colliding nuclei, in search for the critical point of SIM and to study properties of the onset of deconfinement.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Of interest to this programme are thus strangeness production (section 2), fluctuations of baryon density (section 3) and space-time properties of the medium created in heavy ion collisions (section 4  Figure 1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Schematic layout of the NA61/SHINE detector system [1] (horizontal cut in the beam plane, not to scale).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Also outlined are the coordinate system used in the experiment and the configuration of beam detectors used with secondary proton beams for p+p interactions for which φ meson production results are presented.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The main parts of the NA61/SHINE detector system (Fig. 1) were inherited from the NA49 experiment.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Large volume Time Projection Chambers (TPC), two of them immersed in vertical magnetic fields, allow precise measurement of momenta of charged particles down to p T = 0 and provide particle identification (PID) via the dE/dx method.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Time of Flight (ToF) walls complement PID capabilities.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The Projectile Spectator Detector (PSD), a hadron calorimeter, measures forward-going energy allowing to estimate the centrality of nuclear collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions
The φ meson, consisting of s and s valence quarks, is a particle with hidden strangeness.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Motivation for measurement of its production in p+p collisions is twofold.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: First, it is useful in itself to constrain hadron production models.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Second, it may serve as reference for Pb+Pb measurements at the same energies to identify strangeness-related phenomena specific to heavy ion collisions.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: In this contribution, differential multiplicities of φ mesons in p+p interactions at 40, 80 and 158 GeV beam momenta, as a function of rapidity y and transverse momentum p T , are obtained from invariant mass spectra in the φ → K + K − decay channel.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: In Fig. 2 one can see p T spectra in rapidity bins for the 158 GeV data set.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Similar double-differential spectra are also measured for 80 GeV, while due to low track statistics, only single-differential analysis, separately in y and in p T , was feasible for the 40 GeV data.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: These are the first ever differential measurements of φ production at 40 and 80 GeV and the first double-differential measurements at 158 GeV.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Transverse momentum spectra are compared to three models: Epos 1.99 [5,6] from the Crmc 1.6.0 package [7], Pythia 6.4.28 [8] and UrQMD 3.4 [9,10].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Model predictions in Fig. 2 are normalized to the integral of the data in each rapidity bin to focus only on shape comparison.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: One sees that Pythia describes well the shape, while the spectra from UrQMD are too hard and those from Epos too soft.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Having the double differential spectra it is possible to calculate the single differential spectra of rapidity integrated over p T by summation of the measured p T region and extrapolation to large p T .
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The latter is done using a thermally motivated fit function p T e m T /T (thick curves in Fig. 2).
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The unmeasured tail contribution is smaller than 1% for all y bins in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The resulting rapidity distributions are shown in Fig. 3 for all studied energies.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Again the shape comparison with the three models is performed using the same normalization scheme as for p T spectra.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: In this case both Epos and UrQMD predict shapes comparable to that of the data, while Pythia produces a distribution which is too narrow.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: For the largest energy, single differential measurements in narrower rapidity range, are available from NA49 [11].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is clear that the two measurements are consistent.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: In order to calculate total φ multiplicities, distributions are fitted with Gaussian functions 1 (solid curves in Fig. 3).
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Again summation of the measured spectrum is done and the unmeasured tail contribution from the fit is added (3% to 7% depending on energy).
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Then the result is doubled to account for the backward hemisphere from collision symmetry.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The energy dependence of the obtained total φ yields is shown in Fig. 4 and compared to world data [11][12][13][14][15]  [  Figure 4. Energy dependence of total yields of φ mesons in p+p collisions. World data come from Refs. [11][12][13][14][15].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Total uncertainties are shown; for preliminary NA61/SHINE results total uncertainties are smaller than markers.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Red dashed line is to guide the eye.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Regarding models see text.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: consistent with the world data, but are much more accurate.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The figure also shows a comparison of φ yields with models, including the hadron resonance gas (HRG [16]) statistical model.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is apparent that while Epos describes the data reasonably well (although the rise with collision energy is too fast), all other models fail with UrQMD underestimating and HRG overestimating the yield by about a factor of 2.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Figure 5 demonstrates the enhancement of strange meson production in Pb+Pb collisions compared to p+p reactions.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Data on φ in Pb+Pb and other mesons in both systems come from Refs.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions
Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Multiplicities of strange mesons are divided by those of pions to take out the "trivial" effect of the size of the colliding system.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: In case of the φ, the mean total yield of pions is used which was calculated as Ref.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Full circles correspond to results of this analysis, Pb+Pb data come from NA49 [3,4,17], while p+p kaon and pion data are taken from Ref.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions
Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is evident from Fig. 5 (left), that the φ/π ratio increases with energy for both systems.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The enhancement from p+p to central Pb+Pb collisions is about a factor 3.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Dividing the Pb+Pb by the p+p ratios one gets the double ratio:
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: which is shown by the full circles in Fig. 5 (right).
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The analogous ratio for kaons is also plotted in Fig. 5 (right).
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is apparent that the enhancement of φ production is comparable to that of K + , while the enhancement for K − is systematically smaller.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Furthermore the enhancement of φ production is about the square of the K − enhancement, consistent with the hypothesis of strangeness enhancement in a parton phase of the collision.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Finally, Fig. 6 shows the widths σ y of rapidity distributions of φ mesons and various other particles in p+p and central Pb+Pb collisions [3,4,11,[17][18][19][20] as a function of beam rapidity y beam in the centreof-mass frame.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Widths are derived from single or double Gaussian fits depending on the particle species.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is striking that all particles in both colliding systems, except φ in Pb+Pb follow the same trend: σ y is proportional to y beam in the studied range, with the same slope of increase with energy.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: While the effect was already known from Ref.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: [17], the new NA61/SHINE results emphasize the peculiarity of the system size dependence of the longitudinal evolution of φ production, contrasting with that of other mesons.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It should be noted, that the behaviour of σ y for φ mesons in Pb+Pb collisions is qualitatively consistent with rescattering of kaons from φ mesons decaying inside the fireball [17,21].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Such kaons no longer contribute to the signal peak in the invariant mass spectrum.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: It is more likely to take place for slow kaons (i.e. those coming from low rapidity φ mesons), which travel longer through the fireball.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Therefore, the φ rapidity spectrum gets depleted and this loss is the highest at midrapidity and decreases with increasing y values.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: So the spectrum becomes wider due to the rescattering.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: The  Figure 6.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Full circles are results of this analysis, the star is a NA49 measurement in p+p [11], other p+p points come from NA61/SHINE [18,19].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Pb+Pb data are from NA49 [3,4,17,20].
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Lines are fitted to points to guide the eye.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: effect should increase with the collision energy, because the higher the energy, the larger and denser the fireball.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Moreover, it is natural to assume that the effect would be much stronger in a quark gluon plasma, than in a purely hadronic medium.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: This shows the importance of investigating the system size dependence of the effect for systems between p+p and Pb+Pb, for which data are collected by NA61/SHINE.
body_text.section: Hidden strangeness production in proton-proton collisions

body_text.text: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis
In the vicinity of the critical point of strongly interacting matter increased fluctuations in the system are expected in analogy to critical opalescence in liquid-vapour phase transitions.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Therefore the procedure of the search for the CP is to scan the phase diagram of SIM by varying energy and size of colliding nuclei and look for a maximum in fluctuation observables.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Among various fluctuation measures, this contribution focuses on local, power-law fluctuations of baryon density.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: These are studied by calculating second scaled factorial moments F 2 in transverse momentum space (p y vs. p x ) of protons in midrapidity:
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: where the (p x , p y ) space is divided into M bins, n m is the number of protons in bin number m and . . . denotes averaging over events.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: For a critical system, F 2 is expected to scale according to a specific power law with the bin size or equivalently number of bins M. This scaling is called intermittency and the corresponding exponent is called the intermittency index φ 2 [22].
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: However, it is also expected that in addition to protons stemming from a critical system, there is some non-critical background.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: The latter is estimated using event mixing.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: So finally the correlator
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: should scale for M 1 proportionally to (M 2 ) ϕ 2 with intermittency index ϕ 2 = 5/6 [23].
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Figure 7.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Second scaled factorial moments in transverse momentum space for protons in midrapidity for various colliding systems at top CERN SPS energy, measured by NA49 [24] and NA61/SHINE.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Figure 7 shows F 2 (M) as measured by NA49 for several systems at 158A GeV [24].
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: It is seen that data and mixed events plots overlap for the "C"+C and Pb+Pb systems 2 , so no intermittency is observed there.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: In the "Si"+Si system, on the other hand, there is a clear separation of data and mixed events, so ∆F 2 (M) can be calculated and fitted.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: The intermittency index ϕ 2 = 0.96 +0.38 −0.25 (stat.) ± 0.16(syst.) thus obtained is consistent, within uncertainties, 3 with the theoretical predictions for a critical system.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Figure 7 also shows F 2 (M) for the Be+Be system measured by NA61/SHINE at the top SPS energy.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: No evidence for intermittency is observed there, consistent with NA49 results, as the Be+Be system is lighter than "C"+C and therefore yet further away from the "Si"+Si system.
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Finally, the analysis for the heavier Ar+Sc system in NA61/SHINE is ongoing [25].
body_text.section: Search for the QCD critical point via intermittency analysis

body_text.text: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission
Charged spectators in non-central heavy ion collisions generate electromagnetic fields, which modify trajectories of final state charged particles (most of them are pions).
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Oppositely charged particles are affected oppositely, leading to charge asymmetries in distributions of produced particles.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: One example of such asymmetries is charge splitting of directed flow v 1 visible in Fig. 8(a) for Au+Au collisions measured by the STAR experiment [26].
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: It was explained by the spectator-induced electromagnetic (EM) effects assuming that the distance d E between the pion formation zone and the spectator was of the order of 3 fm [27].
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Taking together results of three similar analyses of EM effects in three different data sets on Au+Au and Pb+Pb collisions [26,28,29], the dependence of d E on pion rapidity, shown in Fig. 8(b), was obtained [30].
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: It is visible, that faster pions are produced closer to the spectator system.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: The latter observation was explained in Ref.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: [31] in a new, independent realization of the fire streak model [32], sketched in Figs.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission
Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: (c) and
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission
Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: In the collision centre-of-mass frame, the two incoming nuclei are represented as two continuous, Lorentz-contracted 3D mass distributions defined by the known nuclear density profiles [33].
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: They are then divided into "bricks" in the transverse plane of the collision.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Each brick collides independently with the one from the opposite nucleus, forming a "fire streak".
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: For each pair, local energy-momentum conservation is assumed, which yields the excitation energy E * s and rapidity y s for each fire streak.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: 4 The final ingredient of the model is that each fire streak EPJ Web of Conferences 182, 02082 (2018) https://doi.org/10.1051/epjconf/201818202082 ICNFP 2017 ICNFP 2017 compared to the fire streak model [31]; experimental data are taken from Ref.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission
Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: (d) Shape comparison of rapidity spectra for two extreme centrality classes together with the fire streak model.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: The spectrum for peripheral collisions is renormalized at its peak to central collisions.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: fragments independently into n pions, according to the function [31]:
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: of pion rapidity y with free parameters A, r, σ y independent of the fire streak and collision centrality, = 0.01, and other parameters describing properties of the fire streak stemming directly from the conservation rule.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: From the distribution of fire streak velocities, depicted as thick arrows in Fig. 8(d), and formula (5) one finds that on average, pions produced closer to the spectator system are moving faster.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Summing formula (5) over all fire streaks, one obtains the full rapidity spectrum of pions.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: The fit of the model to data from NA49 [34] for different centrality classes is shown in Fig. 9.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: It is apparent that the model describes well the dependence on centrality of both the yields of pions and shapes of pion rapidity spectra.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: This means that the longitudinal evolution of the system at CERN SPS energies can be interpreted as a pure consequence of local energy-momentum conservation.
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Finally, it should be noted that apart from three measurements leading to the results in Fig. 8(b), an analysis of EM effects for Ar+Sc collisions in the NA61/SHINE experiment is ongoing [25].
body_text.section: Electromagnetic effects in pion emission

body_text.text: Summary
New results on observables relevant for the strong interactions programme of the NA61/SHINE experiment were presented.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: They include the first ever differential measurements of φ meson production in p+p collisions at 40 and 80 GeV beam momentum and the first double-differential measurements at 158 GeV.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: These results were compared to world data on p+p collisions showing consistency and EPJ Web of Conferences 182, 02082 (2018) https://doi.org/10.1051/epjconf/201818202082 ICNFP 2017 EPJ Web of Conferences superior accuracy of the new measurements.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: It was also demonstrated that none of the considered models is able to describe all the properties of φ production in the measured reactions.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Finally, the comparison of p+p to Pb+Pb collisions shows a non-trivial system size dependence of the longitudinal evolution of hidden strangeness production, contrasting with that of other mesons.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The latter observation emphasizes the importance of the analysis of Be+Be, Ar+Sc and Xe+La data collected by NA61/SHINE.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Regarding the search for the QCD critical point, it was shown that there is some evidence from NA49 for intermittency in "Si"+Si collisions at 158A GeV and none detected by NA49 in "C"+C, Pb+Pb, nor by NA61/SHINE in Be+Be interactions at the same energy.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The analysis in Ar+Sc reactions is ongoing.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Spectator-induced electromagnetic effects in pion emission bring information on the space-time position of the pion formation zone, which appears to be much closer to the spectator system for faster pions than for slower ones.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: On that basis, it has been demonstrated that the longitudinal evolution of the system at CERN SPS energies can be interpreted as a pure consequence of local energymomentum conservation.
body_text.section: Summary
